sp.p: Murther, for nought can quench her thirst of lust, but now I soone shall finde hir villany, prais'd bee my vigilant care: which if I doe espie, ile turne her off.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Alas, alas sir, you haue no reason to be angrie, much lesse to be deuorced, although shee doe transgresse, are you not cut? haue ye not giuen her cause, is it not out of meere necessitie she doth it? therefore if you follow my counsaile, make her amends with kindenesse,
and put not her away.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Beleeue me he speakes wisely, and good counsaile, like a Lady, is to be imbraced.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Not put her away, and if she wrong him. If hee doe not, I say he is one of the aranst blocks that euer man spurned on: why is he not a Gentleman, a Knight, hath a not seene fashion: sir, I would haue you beare a noble minde, put her away and you list, tis no matter for cause, if she change but a treneher with the Groome of your stable, tis dealing enough to bee diuorced, Therefore put her away, and then you may haue another wife.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Another wife?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True, a gallant, and yet a modest Lady too, one that shall nourish no blood but your owne, tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, & honour euen your verie footsteps.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: She shall goe, ile make her trusse vp her trinckets, oh faith she shall away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Shall she away? if she doe, you doe you knowe not what, you draw a thousand thousand enemies about your eares, her kindred theill exclaime, no friends will seeke reuenge, and your enemies will growe euen fat with laughter at your folly. Besides: what Woman then will haue you, are you not gelded? assure your selfe that now there is none will loue you, moste will hate you, but all will scorne you, therefore by my aduice make much of her, and keepe her while you haue her.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Hah! now by the vertue of my hearing, he speakes but reason.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: So, tis good to keepe her stil: dwell in the Subburbs to break down your owne glasse windowes, set some pickes vppon your hatch, and I pray professe to keepe a Baudy-house.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A Bawdie-house? no, ile die first, and if I see but any apparent shewe of her disloyaltie, ile euen be diuorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Well, I see the substance of this slaue is villanie.
But ile preuent him euen what I can,
Since none is worse then a Seruing honest man,

div.head: Actus Quarti, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why had I not a good legge? did I not alwaies weare cleane lining? was not my hand washed, my beard comb'd, my cloake brushed, and my shooes blacked, euery morning.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: True, why the more viler strumpet shee to cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: But how doo'st knowe she is with childe.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Knowe it, why shee's dayly troubled with water panges, and quakings ouer her stomacke.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Indeede I must needes say that's a great proofe, shee hath fild her bellie with something that stood against her stomacke, but doost not thinke tis my childe.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Your's! why how can't be your's: are you not circumcised to the quicke?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes, and the rememberance of it galles me.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Thats a signe ye are too patient, and like an Ass eindure all without resistance.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But why doe you laugh sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: To thinke who the childe will be like.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why you, who should it be like else?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why tis none of mine man.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p:
Why the more like you for that: why doe you not not knowe the Philosophers hold the childe is alwaies like the partie which the mother thinkes off in the conception: now she thought moste of you, for feare you should a come the whiles, and thats the reason so many Gentlemens sonnes are like your Cittizens, and calles them fathers too, for otherwise how could it bee
that a young Cockney being left fortie or fiftiie thousand pounds: spends all within so many monthes, but that some young gallant begat him, for you knowe the prouer be, Cat will after kinde. No, had the old Cittizen begotten him, he would a bit a Fig in two, to haue made iust weight, & haue had a pot with a false bottom, rather then a solde too much measure, hee would haue done al things within measure as your olde Citizen did, and not a spend al beyond measure, as your young Gallants doe.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But were not I best goe home and vse her well, till the childe be borne, to see if it be like me, that I may bee sure tis none of mine.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O no, that were base, and as deceitfull as the Collick when it breakes out in winde, which leuels at a mans heele, and it strikes him in the nose, therefore neuer make a show of one thing, and doe an other, but put her away, rid your handes of her, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I thinke whoe's the father of the bastard?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why who's the Father of a Punckes childe? ist not filius populi, it may haue two Fathers for any thing wee knowe.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Well Slacke, I doe verrie much mistrust Wages too, for he is growne verie familiar of late.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True sir, and takes her part too, and ye marke him

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I marke him: no Slacke, no pray heauen a marke not me, but ile instantly sue out a diuorce, hap what hap shall, but ill's his hap whose wife lies down to all.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Of all honest aminall's your Cuckold is the best,
For he is sure a Gentleman, and knowen by his crest.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.l: Of all occupations, that euer man profest,
In my opinion still doth hold, the Cutpursse is the best.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: And why the Cutpursse?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Because he will trust no man, foe as soone as hee hath lone his worke, hee is sure to haue his money in his hand.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Nay then a lawyer is a better trade then that, for he
is sure of his money before hee doth his worke.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But I pray thee what's the newes abroad now?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why they say the worlde is like a Byas bowle, and it runnes all on the rich mens sides: others say, tis like a Tennis-ball, and fortune keepes such a Racket with it, as it tosses it in to times hazzard, and that deuoures all, and for my part they say, twill shortly runne vppon wheeles with me, for my Maister sweares a will haue me carted, because a thinkes I haue layen with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Nay then twill runne vpon wheeles with thee indeed, but peace foole peace, when thou art once marryed, that suspect will die.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace foole peace, saist thou when I am marryed? doost heare? I tell thee, there is no pece in marriage, vnlesse it bee with a dumbe woman, no nor but little comfort neither.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: No way? why doth the Ballad say then, So sweete a thing is Loue, that rules both heart and minde, there is no comfort in the world, to women that are blinde.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Kinde (man) the Ballet saies.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Masse I thinke a be kinde indeed, yet blind's the better of the two I thinke, for as thou saist, if shee be dumbe, I am sure sheele say nothing that shal offend her Husband: if blind, sheele see nothing that shall offend her, and where he nor shee's offended, there must needes be a peace: but besides this is there no peace thinkest thou in the marriage of a wife.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes by the mans, side like a Gentleman onely by the fathers side, but twill nere be any perfit peace.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why, why wilt thou marry then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Because I hope to haue some good behauiour of my wife, for the peace I neuer looke for: but soft ye fellow Slacke, mee thinkes your sute is like a hard hearted Landlord, it begins to receiue great rents.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I, I would, my Maister had giuen me a suite of Buffe when he gaue me this.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p:
Phoe, buffe is naught man, that hath bin out of request
quest euer since Souldiers haue bin out of date, and they poore men are now vsde like Almanackes of the last yeare, either clap-vp behinde the doore, or thrust cleane out of doore: but if thou wilt haue a suite that shall last indeed (lad) get thee a suite of lawe.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O, I doe not like such suites, for commonly they that haue many of them goe almost naked for want of cloaths, yet I cannot denie but they are verrie lasting, but they are subiect to many discommodities: so if there bee any goodnesse in one of them, your Lawyers like mothes, eat shroad holes to it, but your Countrie Atturneyes like lice neuer leaue wrighting and wrangling till they haue crep't into it, but when it hath bin well worne and growne thrid bare, they euen like Lice drop off, and leaue it.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: What saist thou by a suite at court then?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: I marry sir, I like that well, for commonly hee that hath but one suite when hee comes there, hath two ere he come away, for if hee sue by Petition, it lies so long in your Courtiers pocket, that it is another suite to get his Petition backe againe. There is none suddenlie dispatched of his suite there but a Taylor, marrie hee staies not at all, vnlesse his suite bee to haue moneye for his suite, and so hee makes his sute two sutes too ere hee goe. But come, shall wee goe see what followes after our Maisters new diuorce.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why is a diuor'd?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: I, I thinke by this time, for hee swore hee would bee presently. By my troth, I am sorry for it, for in my conscience it is without cause, it grieues me to see him in these humors, for I thanke his Worshippe he hath euer vsed mee well, I am bound to pray for his life.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And mee thinkes thats a strange thing, I see no reason for't that any seruingman should praye for his Maisters life, considering all that he haue, is in reuertion of him: but come, lets followe him, for if hee misse vs, heele fret like a grogram I, and fume like a stue pot.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: And let him fume, O would his gal would burst with indignation, then should his temper procreate my blisse, and I inioy that Saint incarnat: but what shall I doe, since base nor noble shape can win, a third ile trie.
sp.l: And if that faile knight, goe to church and pray,
For vengeance wings brings on thy lethall day.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Hee that a long waie voyage takes in hand, feares dangerous gustes at sea, and stormes:

At land conquering colde that cripels curssed age, and doubts least euerie cloud should proue a storme, & beat his weryed carkasse to the earth. But O, I wold to God my longest Iourney vnto death were to bee tane, for I doe cast no doubts, hauing lost all comfort, My Sonne, I feare, is dead, The losse of him makes life to me but like a blister on my flesh, which grieues mee much, and nought can ease, vnlesse it breakes. O whilst hee liued his presence was a force vnto my age, & gaue it such a luster as did inrich my ring of Life: for life is but a ring beginning in our weakenesse, going round, till vnto weaknes we returne again, then to the ground. The world it selfe is but a skilfull game at chesses, which beeing ended, Kinges and Queenes, Bishops and Knightes into one bags are throwne at last: So all of vs both poore and rich, shall in the end into the earth, as into a Bag be cast-Mans life is like vnto a ship that crost by tempests and by tides, some thoughts of his like billowes swell him vp a loft, another strikes him downe, Thus man as on a sea is toste, in fairest weather feares a storme, and in a storme the euent, but in the ende hee sinckes, when life is spent: griefe hath no boundes in teares, it ebbes and flowes.
Till it haue drowned life, and ended woes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But Wages, is there no meanes (thinkest thou) to turne by it, nor to force backe his streame of wrath.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes ile warrant ye Madam, if youle be ruld by me, you shall see ile make him seeke to be friendes with you, & intreat me to speak for him too, but then I would haue you seeme a little strange: but you shall directly raile on him. Therfore I wold haue ye hide your selues here behinde the hangings, for twill not be long ere hee come this way, and then you shall come foorth and frame your behauiour according as our discourse shall require.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Masse heere he comes, lets stand close.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Wee will, and heauen assist thy proiects.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now Wages, what newes with you?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: That which I thinke will helpe you from beeing diuorc'd.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why your Lady is not with childe.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why how should she, vnlesse some Hobgoblin, some Incubus or spirit of the butterie should beget it? why shee, since you were gelded, neuer saw a man but through a windowe: shee hath neuer trod her foote awry, for feare some ill construction should attend her steps, which like a boundlesse Ocean deepe inrag'd, would drowne her reputation.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Not with childe saist thou?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not of my word sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wages I would thou wouldst but doe some charitable offices.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What? make ye friendes againe?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But youle prooue false, and breake that friendshippe?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Neuer, as I hope to be reconcil'd, therefore tell me, wilt thou doo't?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Hum: truely I would doe my good will, but I feare twill be but labour lost.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I pray thee doe but trie: I faith thou shalt not loose thy paines.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O lasse sir, you know I must feede on Quailes.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: That was in my furie man, but wilt thou not doe it?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Pray sir, if you can get some other friend to speake in 't, do.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well, thou wilt leaue me now then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Alas Sir, what would you haue me doe? by my troth sir, I am asham'd to speake in't: haue yee not gelded and cut off al the content of marriage? why they that haue the full performance of it, tis as much as they can doe to please their Wiues, and you that want all abilitie, must not onely please her now, but make her amends for the wrong you haue done her heeretofore, and how haue I the face to promise that which I knowe you haue no meanes to performe it?

sp.speaker: Kn:
sp.p: Alas man, ile doe my good will.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Doe your good wil, and thats much worth sure, yet since you haue bene my maister, the world shal not say but ile do what I can, ile perswade what I may, ye shal see there shall be no fault in me. Enter the Lady and Nan .Masse heere shee comes: what will you doe now?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: O, Ile hide me here, and so I shall heare all what shee saies.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: O this is excellent, come, come, come, and stand close, ye shall heare how ile speake for ye: and if ye heare your pardon graunted, come forth.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Morrow Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Morrow Mistris Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Morrow Wages.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: The Fox is caught, his head is in the nouse.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: peace, speake soft, perswade, perswade.

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: Faith Madam I haue a sute vnto you, but I am halfe a sham'd to speede in't.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Slight, the rogue saies hee is a sham'd to speake for me, hist Wages, hist wages.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, your man would make an ill suter, that is ashamde to speake in his sute.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What the Diuell aile you, what are you made youle be spide anon.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A pox on thee, art not ashamde to tell her that thou art a shamde to speake for me? hist, hist, Wages.

sp.speaker: Wages:
sp.p: I thinke the Foole rides you, what will you haue?

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Doost heare Wages, speake for me, and by this light ile mend thy Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By how much?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Fortie shillings.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Fortie shillings?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Three pound, three pound.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Giue me your hand, ile do it

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But what's your sute Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: That you would forgiue your Husband,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What and receiue his loue againe, you meane?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Marry there were a iest indeed, being as he is now, a Woman would be loath to turne him amongst her ducks: truely Wages I am ashamde in your behalfe, that a man of your discretion would vrge it, therefore prethe speake no more on't, Ile tell thee what, I could finde in my heart to speake for him my selfe, but that tis such a iealious foole, that if hee catch but a Flea in her bed, hee will be searching to see if it bee a male or a female, for feare a
comes to Cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: Well Wages well: to tell thee truely, I beare no malice, and if I wist hee would amend, I should forgiue and loue him with my heart againe.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ye faith I will wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why how now Wages, haue you betraide vs?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I, Madam, but tis into the handes of those that loue yee.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well Wages well, I did not thinke you would haue vsde vs thus.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is there honestie in this, to set a man behinde the hangings to euise-drop our wordes.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Be not angrie sweete wife, yfaith it was my plot, but you haue beene a heauie enemye of mine.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Twas more for my credit then to haue bene your light friend.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Be friendes with mee good wife, for here I doe confesse.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Your Iealousie sprung from your owne vnworthynesse.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Tis true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then in hope youle kinder prooue, I am content, For this knowe, a Womans heart will soone relent.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.l: Then, come sweete wife, lets in,
And Wages, thy paines deserues to be requited,
For separated hearts, hast thou vnited.

div.stage: Enter Nuecome singing with a Glasse in his hand, and making himselfe ready.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: La, la, la, la, la, they marched out manly by three, and by three, and the formoste in Battaile, was Mary Hanbrie. Will you heare of a Spanish Lady, how shee woed an Englishman: hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Is the Taylor gone?

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: Gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Goe fetch me my doublet their,

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: I goe sir,

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, by the greatest terror to Gentilitie, which indeed is Creditors and Sergeants, this Roaguie Taylor came vppon me with such a bill as a man were better haue ten Constables and their Watches come vppon him with their billes: why good wordes, or a dozen of ale will please them, but nothing will stop this roagues mouthes but money: and yet yfaith I am greatly in his bookes, for though I misuse him neuer so much, yet the Rogue durst not crosse me. Enter Boy .Let mee see Boy, masse tis a prettie Doublet.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Taylor sir, intreates you to remember your day.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: My day? Gods light, my day? why what dooth a take me for, I thinke?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A takes you for a Gentleman sir, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: A Gentleman, and remember my day, no, ile hold my life hee takes mee for some Marchant or Cittizen, but ile make him knowe my strength, ere I leaue him, hee shall finde a second Sampson of mee. I can breake my bonds boy, I can, I can.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: But come sir, will you trye your doublet first.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O I, come, come plucke, but take heede of my ruffe I pray thee: this doublet is too little, a pox in him.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Not now, hee is on sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: No when he is off, I meane boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Beleeue it sir, but it becomes ye well though.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Doth it indeede? masse I thinke it doe, me thinkes I haue a reasonable good legge in't.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: So you haue sir, but your heele is a little too short.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Yea, why too short?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Because your long heele sir doth alwaies best become your great Calfe.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Why? my Calfe is not verrie greate.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: O sir yes, why a man shall not see a greater Calfe of your age, for I thinke you are not aboue twentie.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Not so much, but come helpe off my doublet now.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Come, ile see how twill looke heere, and goe thou and watch the doore, that no body come the whilst, hum, hum, hum, if I had a band for't.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why that about your necke sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: But what if any body should come the whilst?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why doe not I keepe the doore?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Masse that's trew: hum, hum, hum.

O tis Maister Nuecome, I knowe him, a fine Gentleman yfaith ile salute him by and by as I passe. Maister Nuecome I take it, I crie ye hartily mercy good Maister Nuecome, I am glad to see you in good health sir, I shall intreat you to pardon mee, I protest I did not knowe you in that suite, you haue a verrie faire doubleton, the Gods giue you ioy sir: There is neuer a Lord in the Land may be asham'd to weare it sir, rap, rap, rap, rap.
Gods light carrie away my Doublet quickly, quickly, quicklie.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I warrant ye sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Gods pretious my Bande, what shall I doe now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: By yeur leaue sir, my mistris, mistris Peg sent to see how your worship doth.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I thanke her verry heartily, I pray commend me to her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Ile doe your commendations sir, but I pray you bee couered sir, I pray yon be couered.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I thanke ye heartily, tis for mine ease, the weather is hot, hot, verie hot.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: So it is indeede sir, well sir, by your leaue sir, ile be so bold sir as to carrye your commendations sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Doe so good friend, farwell, farwell.

What a beast was I to put off my band, yet the greiefs the lesse, because he came from Peg, which is a Wench I must confesse dotes on my exterior vertues, but I can by no meanes affect hir: onely, because the poore Wretch, in heate of her passion shall not melt her selfe away in teares, shee sometimes inforceth me to sweare and protest I affect her, marry alwaies with mentall reseruations for my soules health, for you knowe that sometimes it is policie Courtiers and Statesmen should vse fallacy.

div.stage: Enter the Lady with a seruant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Giue charge vnto the cooke a make not too much haste with supper, for I hope your maister will be here to night, and looke you keepe fast the doore, let no man trouble me.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Lrd.
sp.p: Now thankes gentle heauens, O bee you smiling stil on my designes, and let your influence poure down good fortunes, and be not angrie, nor no more maleuolent, but make my husbands reconcilement irreuocable.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be shent for letting of you in.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sblood I tell thee I will speake with her, what woldst thou barre my chance when my whole fortunes lies on the cast.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O heauens, stars, fates, Gods smile not like Summer on these Wasps no longer, that daly bussing come to sting my honnour.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Saue thee sweet Lady, I heare thy husband is from home, which makes me come to tender thee my persons loue.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Your parsons Loue (sir) is moste commonly a benefice, O that I should bee troubled with this Asse now, doe you heare sir, if my husband should come and finde you here we were both vndone.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your husband, your husband is an asse, by this light and he should offer you but an ill look in my sight, tweare better he had no eyes: but tis your owne fault that would not ere now accept of the loue of a Souldiar, to haue kept the slaue in some awe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O! how reprochfully the Captaine swaggers, ile away, for feare he grow furious.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But doost heare me sweete Lady, I haue loued thee long, and must now inioy thee. Feare nothing: this warlike sword of mine shal defend thine honour, this Martial blade shall do't: life it shall yfaith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Hark, hark, my husband is come.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Your Husband, ha! where, where?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tis not he? but ile trie my Captaines vallour nowe. O sir, my husband, what shall I doe now, he hath a Pistoll in his hand too, he will kill vs both.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A pistoll? cods my life, what shall I doe then? I pray hide me some where.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O no! as ye loue me, must inioy mee, and will defend my honour, draw forth this warlike sword: this is the martiall blade must doe it, therefore I beseech you good Captaine now or neuer.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p:
Gods pretious woman, he hath a pistoll, a sword no shield against a bullet.
receiue, & then to haue, hold, manure & occupie in statu quo prius, that is in the state before & I do not doubt but your grant in this case will be good, for there is a case that proues this in quinto of Rich the third: a patron was seisd of an aduowsion in fee, with two nuns appendant, & therunto presented a parson, with a prouiso, that if the incumbent shold alien grant, demise, let, set, or otherwise put away the premises, or any part or parcell thereof, that then it should be lawful for the patron (or his assignes) in and vppon the whole to re-enter. The incumbent aliend, the Patron entred, the Quare was, whether those two Nuns were any part of the premises, & by vertue of the prouiso subiect to the reentrie: & after long dispute it was agreed by all the Court, that the entrie was good, as wel in the two Nuns, as in the rest of the premises. Then much more in this case, where we are both lay men.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Sure this fellow thinkes he hath some right to me, & he hopes to win me by law, but what thinke yee: if my husband should come and enter now vpon vs two, in what case were you?

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Why wel enough, perchance he would complaine of me to the bench, and then I shold be put out of commons: that's the worst he could doe, & that 's nothing; for I was once put out of commons before, for beating of the panyard man: and in againe within three daies after.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O Madam, madam, what will you doe? my maister is come as I am a liuing man.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: O lasse sir, what shall I doe with you?

sp.speaker: Exh.
sp.p: Why hide me some where, cannot ye hide me heere?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O no, no, no, he doth vse to search all the house still, to see if he can finde any bodie heere, but ile tell ye what ye shall doe, draw out your rapier and goe out against him, & whatsoeuer question he ask you, make him no answere, but onely say, ye doubt not for all this, but you shall meete him and be reuenged well enough in an other place, and leaue the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Exh:
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come out, come out man.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Slight woman your husband will see me.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Spretious man, that's all one, come out, come out, draw your sword, hold it in your hand, make some showe of resistance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sblood woman he hath a pistoll.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: He hath none, he hath none, by this hand I did but iest.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Yfaith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why will ye not beleeue me? yfaith he hath not.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: Well then, well, nay I care not if he had.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: Why how now Wife, whats the matter? what stirre haue we heere?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why husband did you not meet a man with a rapier drawne in his hand?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes, and heeres another.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Alas husband, he would a kild this poore Gentleman, but that he came and ranne in heere for shelter, and because I would not suffer him spoile him here in your house, he is gone in such a rage as you neuer saw.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: My faith, and he swore indeede hee would be reuenged in an other place: did he not Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: he did indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Beleeue me, and he might easily haue slaine you sir, for he had a very long rapier.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: True, I know my selfe he had the better weapon, or else I would nere a stood so against him.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I, had I such a rapier, I would a made him run like an Irish Lackey.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: I, to haue ouertaken ye.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Wel wife, beleue me, I thank ye for this: for I wold not for the wealth of all this towne he should a hurt him in my house, well sir you shall sup with mee: and after supper ile conduct you to your lodging my selfe, but feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

div.head: Actus Quinti Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why did you not perceiue it?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Not, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O monstrous! why did she not say herselfe, she knew hee had the better weapon, for which cause she stood against him, meaning Bauderie, flat baudery, and yet you could not perceiue it: now by this light, had you slept but one foote lighter, ye had taken them in the verrie fact, but you goe dreaming hanging downe your head, that tis no maruell your wife makes you a Cuckold: for the husband being the wiues head, why when the head goes downe thus, the heeles must needes mount vp.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ile neuer more heare of reconcilement, but bee diuorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Streight put her away, why you may haue wiues enough.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: O wiues too much.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: There's your wiues Kinswoman Mistris rich, vertuous Peg, shee is faire, modest, honest, chaste, wise, sober, discreete and honorable.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And would a be acquainted with me fal'st?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: The man thou speakest of.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why I speake of none, I talke of a woman,

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And haue all these good conditions.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: I, why not?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Doost know her.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Harke then, rent a chamber, hang out her picture, take twelue pence a peece at the least,
sp.l: For enough wil come I knowe:
To see that which none else can showe.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Slight I thinke the man be madde, but will yee not haue her sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p:
Yes, if thou tell true, who would not haue her: but
first make winged speede to purchase my diuorce, holde heere's money, make hast, vse no delay,
sp.l: For all men must for expedition pay.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I goe, and you shall bee diuorc'd or else my braine shall swet: for what your folly looseth, my wit shall get.
sp.stage: Exit Slacke at one doore, and enter Wages at the other.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O Wages, ile tell thee newes, I haue sent for a diuorce, and what wilt thou say when I am marryed to a newe wife?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Then sir will I say as the prouerbe saies, marriage and hanging comes by destinie: but if ye be diuorced, & wil followe my counsaile you shal hang your selfe, rather then marrie againe.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No Wages, I doe not holde that so good: for sure, marriage is better then hanging in some.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: True, in some respect, and that onelye because you haue a longer time of repentance, but I pray sir, ist a christian that you meane to marrie?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A Christian! I, why doost thinke I would marry a Iew?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: I doe not like that so well sir, because it is the fashion amongst them to send Capons to their Godfathers for New yeares giftes, and vppon my life sir, sheele one time or other clap you vp in a basket, and send you away for good handsell: but I pray sir who is it?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Peg, is she not a fine Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Beyond praise.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Hath she not a piercing eye?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And twere a Ferrit.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A delicate nose.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And it were a Mulberrie.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Teeth like two rowes of orient pearle.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But the string is broken & many of them are fallen out.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Hands as white as Pelops shoulder.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I, and as thicke too.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Goe to her, and measure by thy protestations the depth of my affections: tell her what I will bee to her, not what I haue bin to others: if she alleadge to thee her cousens presupposed wronges, tell hir, I well could haue bene hood-winck'd to her cousens faultes, so I had neuer seen her face.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But what shall I tell hir if she say you are gelded?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I there's it indeed, there is no excuse for that: yet thou maist tel her, I did it only to preserue my voice. Deliuer this Iewell to her hand, and with it euen my hearts affection.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I will sir, and if the Wenches close my proiectes carie, spite of mischance you shall your owne wife marry.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now must I be frolicke, learne to speake well, and woo with a good garbe: and now I thinke on't, I haue a pretie conceite of mine owne, I will tell her that the wooing of a young wench, is the felling of a tree, and the getting of her friends good wil, like the lopping of the tree, therefore first it behoues me to hew down the tree & then ile climbe with ease: but if at first to fell it I be not able, t' assay to climbe it shall be in vaine. Welcome, hast thou brought the diuorce.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Tis heere sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Come then, lets in, it ioyes mee much that thou so soone hast sped,
For houres seeme yeares, till it be published.

sp.speaker: Nan..
sp.p: But tell mee good Madam, why are you so melancholly?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: To thinke vpon the sawsie importunitie of my Seruant Slacke: he is like a badge on a coate, he is neuer off, off my sleeue, and yet I shun him like the pest.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And he followes you like infection.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay I would he did so by me, for I protest I loue him beyond my thoughts, I couet nothing like his company, and yet he hates me, lothes my sight, but then comes the welchman your loue, and he hanges on my lips like a Padlocke on a Pedlars Budget.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And hates me as much, for if I come but neare him, hee sweares I am like a Kybe, alwaies at his heeles.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Come Madam, doe not grieue at that which griefe can no way mend.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: I would not, if I could mend that which doth cause my griefe.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Newes, newes.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What newes.

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: You are diuorced.

sp.speaker: La,
sp.p: Why diuorced, why? ha, speake.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot speake the cause Madam? but questionles tis true, and mistris Peg, my maister nowe makes loue to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: To thee, I to thee, go thy waies, thou shalt be a Lady, I euer thought thou wouldst come to some promotion, as the boy did that had a bag and a staffe and beg'd for himselfe, but how dost thou knowe he is in loue with her.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Know't why I haue seene him stand an houre togither behinde an Oaken tree, calling it sweet mistris, kind Peg and making speeches to it.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: As how? as how? prethee how?

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: Stand you for the tree, and ile speake for my Maister.

sp.speaker: Nan..
sp.p: I will, and that moste stifly yfaith.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Then thus he begins: Deare mistris Peg I must confesse.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay then hee is a dead man already.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Na,,
sp.p: Why confesse and be hang'd euer.

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: O ho, but I meane he doth confesse shee's faire.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Thats all one, hee's but one man, and one witnesse can neuer proue her fact, but prethee on with thy speech.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why then this faire Mistris I must confesse.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But he will not confesse before witnesse will he?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Push, did not I tell you he would speake to an Oke.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, then that will bee a strong proofe indeed.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Proofe, Nay, if that be not proofe, how say by this token.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: I marry sir, would wee had more such tokens of his loue.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: This Mistris he hath sent to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Looke you Madam, your husband now makes loue to me.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Sir how peart thou art, why looke woman, your loue as mad woes mee, and to me sent this ring.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And my man the man you so esteeme, spite of refusall left with mee this chaine.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: This chaine: for euer may he lincked bee to woe, that hates my loue, and woes another so.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Well, lets in, and be but patient all a while, for if the worst doe fall, that euer did fall,
A plots in chace that shall out strip them al

div.stage: Enter Knight and Cupid before him.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Now if shee should refuse my Iewell and contemne my loue, or contemne my loue, and take my Iewell: what a foole was I to send her a token till I had some token of her affection, as if women might be woed with giftes, for when we giue them those things which moste wee loue, they doe esteem we loue them better then those things we giue, when they poore fooles doe but deceiue themselues, for we doe live as Marchants venter, for a treble; again we send them tokens only to get them and their portions. But there comes my persecutor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why doost thou haunt me like a Ghost, thou femall inner: thou hast not holy church in thy power with all hit
commaundements, to keepe mee from thy vnhallowed presence: how durst thou break the Edict pronounced by the mouth of holy Church Man? art thou not Diuorced? is not our separation blowne into the peoples eares, euen by Iehouahs chosen Trumpetter? First, thou didst breake thy vow to mee, and madest of euery Priapus a Trumpet; on which thou blowedst thine owne infamie: therefore auoide, thou leauend lumpe of sinfulnes, auoyd.

O my still beloued Husband, like filth or durt, doe not flea me like a Serpent, which comes to sting thy bosome; I come to kisse; Sweet let not suspect diuorce me from thy presence, though from thy bedde:
For if you will trust this masked face, I knowe:
No fountaine purer than my Loue would show.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I flie, and hate thee like a Serpents hissing, which comes to sting me with pretence of kissing.

O faintie teares, and feeble handes, for euer may you close, and neuer part till sharpest griefe haue cut the heart-strings of my life. Or else let this same braine of mine dissolue to teares, and droppe it selfe euen drop by drop, vntill it make a Sea of woes, that therein I may drowne my wretched life.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Alas poore Ladie, I pittie your calamitie, and grieue to see you bruised by my Maisters iniurie, which makes your eyes like spunges drop these brinish teares, and spoyles a Face, such as was neuer better one framde by the skilfull hand of Nature.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Auoyd thou slaue, how durst thou woe mee? I am like a starre to thee; my Orb's aboue thee.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: O! then my Loue is a most cleare and brightest starre: look not with a maleuolent Aspect vpon me, but let your eyes bright raise vp my life, and so extoll my thoughts

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Perish may thy selfe and loue together:
Heauens graunt againe, I nere may heare of eyther.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Respect her most, that most of all loues you.
sp.p: O! doe not turne away those Eyes, whose radiant beames first nursd my flame.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Auoyde thou vnresistable Torteror, more fretting to my thoughts then Cankars are to Mettalls. How often haue I tolde thee of my hatred? For of this bee thou sure and still remembred: deepe hate (like loue) can hardly be dissembled.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I, doest thou hate me then? O brightest Venus,
Now or neuer make thy blinde Sonne see; and wound his heart, whose hate hath wounded mee.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Oh here shee is; pray God my Band sit well. Faire Lady, may I presume with the Bee to sucke Hony from thy lippes, for I dream'd the last night.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay, I thought he would wooe me dreaming like a Welshman.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: That I was transfigured, metamorphosd, or transform'd into a flea in thy Bed.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But did I not kill yee then?

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Me thoght you did did, but first I dream't I flung you.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Yet againe dreaming, ile talke no more, but be gon; for feare I wake him.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: And then me thought, as I was skipping from your knee vnto your thigh, & so forth; you told a Gentleman of it, a friend of yours; who most courtly and softly putting in his hand to catch mee. Spretious shee's gone, sure t'is the acutenes of my ingenuitie, which makes my ieasts so stinging, as she cannot endure them: I must needs eat some of your new court-water-gruell, to qualifie my my inuention.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Thou need'st not loue, speake what thou wilt, if gently thou doe speake, thy words to mee are much more Musicall then is a Syrens voyce. Orpheus himselfe could neuer straine his high stretch'd strings to such Melodious sounds, as when thy voyce doth pierce the eare.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: T'is but for my wit she loues me: I sent her trickes alreadie: for Courtyers must aswell thriuing bee, Haue Noses to smell out, as Eyes to see.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Despis'de, and left alone, filde brim full of griefe, and no way to vnloade mee of my cares.
But through these running eyes, in streames of teares.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Whose teares like to a cleer, yet poysoned source, haue with their vapours through these eyes (the windowes to my heart) infected all my thoughts. Thy eyes do shoote forth glances like to starres, though seated in a moyste and rainie Skie, the which hath wounded euen my heart, and I must die; Lest Achilles launce-like, healed by your eye.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I pray you seeke some-where else, if you bee ill,
For I in Surgerie-haue little skill.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Ile follow my sute, not ceassing till the most of triall,
For hee's a foole in Loue that makes denyall.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.p: Here hath bene a Maze, a Round, a Whyrling in Loue,
sp.l: How like the spoakes of a Ladyes Coach-wheeles
They runne one after another:
And as of them you see neyther,
So none of these can ouertake eyther.
And though you see them thus forsaken,
They shall be marryed, but mistaken:
Which for performance yet a while,
I must be labouring to beguile.
Onely the men, and make them venter,
To runne a Circle farre from Center
Of their hopes; yet for their good,
Where blinded each like Hawke in hood,
Shall Marry better then they Wooed.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Nay Madame, it must needes bee so, or else the Priest will neuer Marrie me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And so you would haue vs all bee Marryed masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: True, to which you all may easily perswade your Louers, telling them with my Marriage, will be with much the lesse suspect effected.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: But say, who shall knowe vs, when our Faces are not seene?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: The better; for then you shall appoint each one of them, to chuse you by theyr owne Tokens, which you within your selues shall chaunge: Mistris Peg shall weare Mistris Nans Ring, Mistris Nan your Chaine, and you Mistris Pegs iewell.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: But shall they neede to come naked too?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O I, by any meanes, onely for some priuate reasons vnto mee, in which perswasion if you will practise that you know, you will preuaile.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ile doe my best most willingly.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.l: Then come Madam, let's in: I know it will doe.
For this is held a principle in Schooles,
Loue makes not fooles wise men, but wise men fooles.

sp.p: Nominatiuo, hic, haec, hoc.
A Nowne is the name of a thing.
Amo, amas, amaui, amare.
In speech be these eight parts.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: I promise you sir, I had Dinde forth to day, but that you see the weather is Clowdie, and the Heauens lowre on my delights.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I pray you sir, whose Sonne is that bigger Boy?

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p:
It is Maister Parmisins sonne the Cheese-monger, and the next to him is Maister Cauetas sonne the Ferry-man,
two very prettie sparks ile assure you. Tobias Parmasin, come hither Tobias, holde vp your head Tobias, and looke and you can see a penny in my browe: So, t'is well done; What part of speech is Mentula?
A nowne Adiectiue.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And why a nowne adiectiue?
Because it stands not by himselfe, but it requires an other word to be ioyned with it.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Marke you Syr, I teach both substance and meaning; I doe not teach as your common people, d, o, b, a, b, b, bottles; Goe sit you downe againe Tobyas, Timothie, come yee hither Timothie: How construe you this verse Timothie? I am, iam, Tacturus, Sidera summa putes.
I am, iam, O Iohn, Iohn, putes, doe thou put, Sidera, summa, Syder in Summer, Tacturus, in Tankerds.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: A very forward childe, I promise ye.

sp.speaker: Maist. C.
sp.p: Goe sit you downe againe: Will you heare them all examined Syr?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Mosse willingly good good Maister Correction.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Yee shall sir; Syr, I haue taken as much paines with them, as anie Poet whatsoeuer could haue done, to make them answer vpon their Q. with good action, distinction, & deliberation: ha, ha, ha, how many diuels are there?
Number infinite.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Looke you Syr, there are an infinite number of Diuels: What is the Diuell?
A wicked Spirit.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the nature of that wicked spirit?
To worke mischiefe.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: On whom doth it worke mischiefe?
On all mankinde.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: When hath he most power to worke mischiefe?
When Man hath taken his liquor.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: With what visitations then deludes he mankinde?
With strange Earthquakes.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the mans best comfort?
To sleepe and slumber.

sp.speaker: M. Cor.
sp.p: Looke ye now sir, are they not pretty children?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Very prettie, and well taught, Ile assure you sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Sir, I will tell you, notwithstanding all these paines I take with them, yet how vnkindely their Parents vse me: they suffer theyr younger Children to beray the Church-porch: And no longer since then Munday last, came the Officiall, and there beeing angrie with mee about other matters, hee threwe that in my dish, as if I could haue helped it: but I answered him sufficiently: For I tolde him, they that did it, were but the Children and the youth, and youth would breake out in despite of his Nose; or the best mans Nose in the parish.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I thinke yee spend most of your time with your Schollers heere: yee keepe little other companie.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Yes sometimes sir, here was yesterday Maister Nucome the Courtier, doe you not knowe him sir?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: O very well sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Hee is a fine Gentleman, a good Scholler, and an excellent Naturalist: and truly fell into a great disputation, (peace these Boyes there) and our Argument was, whether a Foole or a wiseman made the best Lawyer. He stood for the Wise man, and I most Scholastically, stoode for the Foole: and thus I began my Syllogisme, (peace these Boyes when I bid ye) your wiseman (said I) vseth few words, your Foole, much babling; your best Lawyers vse much babling. Ergo, your Fooles makes the best Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And belieue me sir, t'was well prooued.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: A flash, a flash, a foolish Schoole-point, a foolish Schole-point.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O I, and confuted mee too, onely by reason of a scuruie old Prouerbe which sayes, Children and Fooles doe alwayes tell true: but your best Lawyers doe not alwayes tell true: Ergò, your Fooles make not your best Lawyers, a most strong and strange Argument.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I pray Maister Correction, let mee intreat a Play-day for your Schollers.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: O Maister Wages, they do nothing else, they do nothing but play, nothing but play.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Nay good sir, do not deny me, for I haue some priuate busines with you of great importance.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay then sir you shall preuaile indeed: you shall, yet I remember; Dyonisius ille Tyrannus, Scyciliae crudelissimus, crudelissimus Sciciliae Tyrannus ille Dyonisius: sayes to one of his Pupils: Hue ades, haec animo, concipe dictatuo. So I say vnto you all my Maisters, reuerere Maiores: plucke off your Hats to your betters, and looke yee giue the Woman the wall, and so goe your wayes.

div.stage: Omnes Gratias: Gratias: Gratias: Gratias: Exeunt omnes Schollars.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Morrow Mistris Correction.

sp.speaker: Mistris Cor.
sp.p: Morrow good Wages.

sp.speaker: Maister Corr.
sp.p: Morrow sweet Wife, sweete Frisset, sweet Nuptiall.

sp.speaker: Mistris Corr.
sp.p: O Maister Wages! how doth your good Maister, sir Timothie Troublesome? what, doth he thinke he is a Cuckold still?

sp.speaker: Maist. Corr.
sp.p: An arrant Cuckold (Wife) belieue it.

sp.speaker: Mistris Corr.
sp.p: Come, come, Husband, you are such another; why doe you say so?

sp.speaker: Ma. Corr:
sp.p: Because it is true, Wife.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Syr, Maister Correction you are mistaken, I thinke hee be no Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor:
sp.p: Good Maister Wages talke no more of Cuckolds; I would they were all in the Sea for my part.

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: Husband, can you swim?

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: No Wife, nor I desire not to learne.

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: I would haue you in any case appoint with my Husband that I may come masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Peace, that plot is already drawne, Maister Correction, I am sent vnto you from my maister, who commends his Loue vnto you, intreating you will giue your diligent attendance this Euening at the Church, because himselfe vpon his Diuorce, is priuately to be marryed to a new wife: three other couples he brings with him, they all come masked, yet I will giue you priuate notice what each one is: onely I must desire you not to saile.

sp.speaker: Maist. Cor.
sp.p: Maister Wages, your Maister is the helme by which my labours are gouern'd: and tell him I will steare all the nauie of my actions by his directions: And so pray commend me backe to him.
Well sir then, till then Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mai. Cor.
sp.p: The like to you sir. Come Wise, I hope that thou shalt thriue, for as all your Cockatrices maintaine surgions by theyr issues: So doth the Priest and Midwife agree: I set them together, they make worke for thee.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And truely Husband, ile come to their labours, be it at midnight, if they send for me.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Doth my Tyre sit well Nan?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Passing well, ile assure you Madame.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Prethee tell me too, how am I drest?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why thou art very well drest too, but basted admirably: for the threedes sit in thy Gowne, Marrie thou wantst a little Cramming.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And that's pittie; for I can tell you, I am of my selfe a rare bit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay then thou art for the Seruingmen, for your Gallants (I can assure you) ride altogether with a snaffle.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, thou hast such a deale of wit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeede I had, before I spent it amongst such vnthankfull persons as you are Peg; but I prethee pinne, my Gowne close before: for it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That I will, but why then doest thou obscure thy Brauerie? this thy Petticoate is a great deale richer then thy Gowne.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith I, I weare my cloathes as your Gallants we are their wits, the best side inwards, I scorne to show it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But for all this Idle talke, I would we had appointed our marriage to morrowe morning.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Then the people would a stood gazing on vs, and besides, we should haue bin like thee in dutch, subiect to euerie Coblers interpretation, but now being marryed in the euening, presentely bed time followes.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Phoe, but tis not the fashion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Tut, hang fashion, I loue it in nothing but my cloathes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, thou knowst tis not the fashion in all places to lie with ones owne husband euerie night. Slight I had rather lie with a man, and neuer marrie him, then marrie a man and neuer lie with him, come, come, I speake my minde freely, I am none of these simpering wenches that come at euerie, word & saies I forsooth, & no forsooth, & blushes at the sight of a childe, it puts her in minde how twas made & cries faugh at a wanton lest in a plaie, and harkens to a baudie tale in her eare.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I, tis but dishonorable to marrie thus in hugger mugger, men will say we are with childe, and are asham'd to shew our faces.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Our faces! why our faces I hope do: not show vs to be with childe, tis out bellies showes that, and I hope thou art quicke flesh and not dead fish, thou wilt not turne vp the white of thy belly, woo't? but prethee tell me, was I not marryed yesterday?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yesterday, why doost aske?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Because, like a young marryed woman that's poisoned before shee is baud, I begin to long alreadie.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: For what I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Faith to be a bed with my husband.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'alas woman, those that are past childe bearing, vse to long for that too.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay, but my longing yet me thinkes stretches a great deale longer, for I long to be a Widdow, that I might haue a new Husband: yet not for any concupiscent desires, that I haue in the world.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I thinke so too, but onely a desire thou hast to trie the difference of men, and therfore I thinke thou wert best next to marrie an olde man with a white head, because thou maiest sleep quiet & not be troubled a nights.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By this light I had as liue marrie a Saint Dauis Leeke, no, no, take this of me, where euer thou seest the Snowe lye on the Mountaines, be assured there's no great heate in the vallie.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Let me see, I would be a—

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: A Priestes wife I warant ye, because thou wouldest fare costly, and liue lasily.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No Nan, then marrie a Londoner, for then thou shalt liue a life & twere a Lady, weare thy golde necklace, and goe in thy Veluet cap euerie day.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: True, and then when thy husband is a broad in trafficke for commodities, in other countries, why thou maist deale at home for ready money

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: No not a Londoner by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why if they haue but a plague amongst them one weeke they all crie out of a dead time streight, besides, if they receiue but a little losse at sea, they breake streight, and where the husband breakes, you knowe the wife can no longer hold out, she must downe too for want of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay then marrie a Souldier, for questionlesse most of them will vse their wiues wel, for they loue their punkes exceedingly.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: O but they haue a vile sault too, for they alwaies beget their children by day, and then they be squint eyed, for when the Father lookes one way, and the mother another, to see if any body come the whilst, how can the childe look right?

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: What saist thou by a Ciuilian Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
O no, by no meanes, for moste of their posteritie haue ill lucke, for what their fathers get by baudie courts, they commonly spend it all againe in baudie houses, No and euer I marry againe, ile marrie an Irish Marchant, because they all speake latine, and indeed are moste of them Philosophers by fortune: Omnia mea mecum porto, for they carry all their ware in their breech: but come, let vs make hast
away, I feare out louers doe our comming stay.

div.stage: Enter the old Lord, and the Marchant.

sp.speaker: Old Lord:
sp.p: You see maister Venter, the greatest comfort that is left me now, is onely in my neighbours loues, where are these knaues there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: What haue they sup'd within.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not yet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Why so, thou art an honest knaue, goe see that none want wine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: I would not haue the worst complaine of scarcitie or want of any thing, for Maister Venter wee shall carrie nothing with vs, for naked we into the world came, without that which we now possesse and haue, and without it we must vnto the graue. Enter Sir Iohn Correction .O Sir Iohn, Sir Iohn, I thanke you for your homelye to day, but it you haue a fault sir Iohn, the which in any of your Schollers would deserue a whipping: you are come to late, I and to a feast and all, well, well, well, but you shall fare the worse for this sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ma. Co:
sp.p: I would desire a word in priuate with your honou.

sp.speaker: Old Lor:
sp.p: With all my heart: They Whisper They shall be welcome, euen exceeding welcome, and I thanke you too.

Harke you neighbour, Sir Iohn tels mee that to honnour me in this my predecessors still accustom'd feast, foure new marryed couples are heather come in a maske, newlie from the church, their feete not yet since their nuptiall, haue kisd their owne thresholds.

div.stage: Enter Maister correction, Cupide and the maskers dauncing

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Tis Signe ye are well belou'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: I am indeede Maister Venter, I am indeede.
Gentlemen and Women, yee are all welcome euen with my heart, I with my heart yfaith. O neighbour Venter my Sonne and your Daughter now bee marryed, what a ioyfull maske would this haue bin.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Tis true my Lord, but they are fled beyond all hope of euer seeing them againe.

sp.speaker: Old Lo.
sp.p: Tis trew, tis trew, yet though the frute gone be, my griefe you see, like leaues sticke fast vppon this tree. but come neighbour come, lets sit & look vpon this youthfull dauncing mirth, for youth and mirth haue daunc'd themselues out at heeles with me.
Nay, pray Gentlemen vnmaske, that we may knowe to whome we shall be thankful for this honour, how now my Sonne?

div.stage: The first couple vnmaske and kneele.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: My Daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Now may my blessiug raise thee from the ground.

sp.speaker: Ven:
sp.p: And mine make thee both fruitfull, and a faithfull wife.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Why what are you?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Mistook of you, but such is womans fantasie,
Constant in nothing but vnconstancie:
For I that first you moste abhord,
Lou'd you a slaue, and hated you a Lord.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.l: Well, woodcocke like by thy bill, tis my hap,
Thus fast to be catched in a womans trap.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Now by my conscience I am deceiu'd.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: No, not a whit, for I will loue you euer.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.l: Well, giue me your hand then, since tis my fate,
What marriage ioines, Ile neuer separate.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What now ,remaried? Sir Timothy and his wife vnmasked

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O! I repent it not, this match is double made, and twice hath holy Hymens fingers tide the knot.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Well, since tis thus hence foorth ile loue thee euer, for que sera, sera, gainst what plots so euer, but who is this, maister Correction?

sp.speaker: Ma. Co.
sp.p: A friend of yours. They vnmaske .Spretious tis my wife.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O then sir tis a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: Come ye away huswife, come ye from him, come.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Faith sir no, why is he not my husband? did not you your selfe marrie me to him? but doe you heare, you were best be quiet and let me alone, if not, yfaith ile tell all.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: Tell what thou canst, iustice my Lord Iustice, I beseech ye for Iustice.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech your Lordship too, though I am but a weake vessell called a Woman, & therefore by reason of my bashfulnes vnable sir to set foorth mine owne tale, yet I doubt not, but I shal finde good hearing at your Lord ships hand, if ye wil but giue me leaue to open mine own case.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Speake, what are your greeuances.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: May it please your honour in few words, my husband hath foure wiues, and then I hope tis as lawfull for me to haue two husbands.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: How doe you answere this Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: And like your honour, I thinke tis as lawfull for me to haue foure wiues, as tis for my parson to haue foure benefices, considering I vse them as he dooth his benefices, for I protest to your honour, I neere came neare none of them.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Will not this doe it Maister Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No, you see he hath answerd it.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Nay then and it like your Lordship, I may bee diuorc'd for another thing, but that I am ashamd to speake on't.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, you must tell what tis.

sp.speaker: M. Cor.
sp.p: Truely I am halfe ashamde.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Come, come woman, neuer be a shamde to tell (true.

sp.speaker: Mi: Cor.
sp.p: And I may be so bolde to tell your honour in priuate.

sp.speaker: Old Lo.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Truely and like your honour, he hath not that a man should haue.

sp.speaker: Old. Lo.
sp.p: No, why what doth he want.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay pray your Lordshippe to spare me now, faith I am asham'd.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Nay good Mistris Correction, I must knowe what it is.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Why then sir I must needes tell: truely a hath neuer a beard.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.l: Indeede a man should haue a beard.
Well mistris correction, your husband must haue you backe againe:
And thus in friendship endes long Iealious strife,
With all thinges well, saue Wages wants a wife.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: BVt Gentlemen, whose iudgements sit
in strict commission on the wit:
Which from the Authors pen did flowe
He wisheth at all but this to knowe.
that if you well doe censure him,
He redie is with brains and pen,
Another time to pleasure you,
If not, he bids you all adue.
For well he knowes he hath done wels
And so he boldly dares to tell.
Yet for the children ere I goe,
Your censure I would willing know.
For if you doe the Action blame.
They readie are with pardon drawne
And each of them heere hoping stands
That you will signe it with your hands.
